content:
IN “ass="word-wrap-span">FIRST ass="word-wrap-span">BLOOD”, David Morrell’s action-thriller novel from 1972, ass="word-wrap-span">John ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo returns to ass="word-wrap-span">America from Vietnam, where he fought in an elite ass="word-wrap-span">Special ass="word-wrap-span">Forces unit. ass="word-wrap-span">Afflicted by post-traumatic stress disorder, he attacks the local police when they try to detain him and flees to the mountains. ass="word-wrap-span">After a manhunt, in which officers and ass="word-wrap-span">National ass="word-wrap-span">Guardsmen die, ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo hopes to meet an honourable end. His former captain shoots him in the head.

ass="word-wrap-span">The novel was adapted into a film in 1982, and its final scene had ass="word-wrap-span">The hero (played by ass="word-wrap-span">Sylvester ass="word-wrap-span">Stallone) being put out of his misery. ass="word-wrap-span">But when it was screened for test audiences, ass="word-wrap-span">They hated it. ass="word-wrap-span">The film-makers chose instead to write a stirring speech for ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo, in which he recites a litany of complaints widely held among veterans of ass="word-wrap-span">The war, before escaping ass="word-wrap-span">The clutches of his pursuers. “ass="word-wrap-span">Somebody wouldn’t let us win,” he shouts. “ass="word-wrap-span">Then I come back to ass="word-wrap-span">The world, and I see all those maggots at ass="word-wrap-span">The airport, protesting me, spitting, calling me baby killer and all that vile crap.” It was a box-office hit, and ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo promptly became a cultural phenomenon.

ass="word-wrap-span">Just a few years earlier, films about ass="word-wrap-span">The war in Vietnam had a more dejected feel. “ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Deer ass="word-wrap-span">Hunter” and “ass="word-wrap-span">Coming ass="word-wrap-span">Home” (1978) supported ass="word-wrap-span">The troops but questioned ass="word-wrap-span">The war itself by documenting ass="word-wrap-span">The hardships faced by veterans returning to civilian life; with its original ending, “ass="word-wrap-span">First ass="word-wrap-span">Blood” would have fit neatly among ass="word-wrap-span">Them. ass="word-wrap-span">Instead, ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo’s rewritten speech reflected a new attitude towards recent ass="word-wrap-span">American history. In 1980 ass="word-wrap-span">Ronald ass="word-wrap-span">Reagan had campaigned for ass="word-wrap-span">The presidency on a platform of optimism, which required a renewal of ass="word-wrap-span">America’s belief in its military might. “ass="word-wrap-span">First ass="word-wrap-span">Blood” chimed with ass="word-wrap-span">Reagan conservatism, which emphasised ass="word-wrap-span">American exceptionalism, ass="word-wrap-span">The need for a muscular foreign policy and a loathing of big government.

ass="word-wrap-span">The subsequent “ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo” films gave ass="word-wrap-span">American audiences a chance to re-fight ass="word-wrap-span">The Vietnam war and emerge with ass="word-wrap-span">Their national pride renewed. In “ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo: ass="word-wrap-span">First ass="word-wrap-span">Blood ass="word-wrap-span">Part II” (1985) ass="word-wrap-span">The hero is recruited by his ass="word-wrap-span">Commander to rescue prisoners of war left behind by ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">American government. At ass="word-wrap-span">The time of ass="word-wrap-span">The film’s release, ass="word-wrap-span">The idea that ass="word-wrap-span">There were still ass="word-wrap-span">American soldiers in Vietnam was a fringe ass="word-wrap-span">Theory—it was officially debunked by a ass="word-wrap-span">Senate ass="word-wrap-span">Select ass="word-wrap-span">Committee in 1993—but ass="word-wrap-span">The film treats it as fact. “Do we get to win ass="word-wrap-span">This time?” ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo asks before accepting ass="word-wrap-span">The assignment. “ass="word-wrap-span">This time, it’s up to you,” his ass="word-wrap-span">Commander responds.

ass="word-wrap-span">The sequel was a sensation, grossing $300m at ass="word-wrap-span">The global box office. Its biggest fan resided in ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">White ass="word-wrap-span">House. ass="word-wrap-span">Towards ass="word-wrap-span">The end of ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">Beirut hostage crisis in 1985, ass="word-wrap-span">Reagan said that “after seeing ‘ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo’ last night, I know what to do ass="word-wrap-span">The next time this happens.” ass="word-wrap-span">The character’s symbolic power extended to domestic policy, too. In a speech about tax breaks, ass="word-wrap-span">Reagan began: “ass="word-wrap-span">When I think of all ass="word-wrap-span">The good people who’ve pleaded with ass="word-wrap-span">The federal government for years to clean up our tax structure, I am reminded of a recent, very popular movie—and in ass="word-wrap-span">The spirit of ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo, let me tell you we’re going to win this time.”

“ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo III” followed in 1988, with ass="word-wrap-span">The protagonist teaming up with ass="word-wrap-span">The mujahideen in Afghanistan to save a friend kidnapped by ass="word-wrap-span">Soviet forces. ass="word-wrap-span">The most expensive film ever made at that time, it was a flop in ass="word-wrap-span">America compared with its predecessors. ass="word-wrap-span">Reagan was in his last year of office; ass="word-wrap-span">The idea of out-and-out victory had become more complicated over ass="word-wrap-span">The course of ass="word-wrap-span">The cold war. ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo’s on-screen alliance with rebel soldiers was a prelude to a new, murkier global era. ass="word-wrap-span">The franchise took a two-decade hiatus.

ass="word-wrap-span">When ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo returned in 2008, ass="word-wrap-span">The year Barack Obama was elected president, ass="word-wrap-span">The ass="word-wrap-span">American right had new villains. ass="word-wrap-span">Now middle-aged, in “ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo” ass="word-wrap-span">The hero is living a quiet life in ass="word-wrap-span">Thailand ass="word-wrap-span">When he is recruited by ass="word-wrap-span">American missionaries to guide ass="word-wrap-span">Them to a war zone where ass="word-wrap-span">Christian farmers are being slaughtered. ass="word-wrap-span">They are captured and ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo springs to life, murdering hundreds of ass="word-wrap-span">Burmese soldiers in gruesome fashion. ass="word-wrap-span">Although ass="word-wrap-span">The film is set on foreign soil, ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo’s mission echoed ass="word-wrap-span">The sentiments of ass="word-wrap-span">Republicans at home, some of who felt that ass="word-wrap-span">American ass="word-wrap-span">Christianity was under attack by ass="word-wrap-span">The election of a president who ass="word-wrap-span">They were convinced, despite evidence to ass="word-wrap-span">The contrary, was neiass="word-wrap-span">Ther ass="word-wrap-span">Christian nor ass="word-wrap-span">American.

It grossed only $113m worldwide, yet its success was enough to justify one ass="word-wrap-span">Last instalment, “ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo: ass="word-wrap-span">Last ass="word-wrap-span">Blood”, which was released on ass="word-wrap-span">September 20th. ass="word-wrap-span">This film again echoes ass="word-wrap-span">Republican rhetoric, as ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo crosses into ass="word-wrap-span">Mexico to avenge the daughter of a family friend who is kidnapped, drugged and raped there. He lures the criminal back over the border to ass="word-wrap-span">America so he can fight him on his own soil. ass="word-wrap-span">Despite Mr ass="word-wrap-span">Stallone’s recent insistence that the ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo films never intended to make political statements, it is hard to ignore how his imagined war with Mexican villains dovetails with ass="word-wrap-span">Donald ass="word-wrap-span">Trump’s views on immigration. ass="word-wrap-span">When ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo kills them, he is enacting a fantasy shared by some of the president’s supporters.

ass="word-wrap-span">Compared with its influence in the 1980s, ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo is a franchise in decline. “ass="word-wrap-span">Last ass="word-wrap-span">Blood” has been eviscerated by critics—its rating on ass="word-wrap-span">Rotten ass="word-wrap-span">Tomatoes, a review-aggregator site, is a paltry 28%—but it has matched the opening weekend ticket sales of the 2008 film and is on track to turn a solid profit. It indicates that, for some of the ass="word-wrap-span">American public, the jingoism and military strength that ass="word-wrap-span">Rambo symbolises continues to appeal.
